Title: Ethereum Foundation Launches Portal Showcasing ZK Privacy Tech to RWAs and Restaking
Description:
The (EF) has launched “Ethereum for Institutions,” a new online portal designed to guide enterprises, financial institutions, and developers looking to build on Ethereum's infrastructure. 

1/ Now live: the Ethereum for Institutions siteEthereum is the neutral, secure base layer where the world's financial value is coming onchainToday, we're launching a new site for the builders, leaders, and institutions advancing this global movement — Ethereum Foundation (@ethereumfndn) 

In a series of posts on X, the foundation said the initiative marks Ethereum's continued evolution into the backbone of the global on-chain economy — uniting privacy-preserving technology, real-world assets, and institutional staking within a single framework.A New Institutional Gateway to Ethereum

The launched by EF's Enterprise Acceleration team, provides a roadmap for organizations adopting Ethereum. The platform offers resources and technical pathways to support institutional adoption.

“Ethereum is the neutral, secure base layer where the world's financial value is coming onchain,” stated. “Clear pathways are essential as institutions build.”

The site highlights Ethereum's decade-long reliability — with over 1.1 million validators and continuous uptime — while spotlighting leading companies such as BlackRock, Visa, eToro, and Coinbase, which already manage billions in assets and trillions in transaction volume using Ethereum-based solutions.ZK Privacy and Compliance: The Next Institutional Frontier

Recognizing privacy as a key institutional requirement, the Ethereum Foundation emphasizes the use of zero-knowledge (ZK) proofs, fully homomorphic encryption (FHE), and trusted execution environments (TEEs) to enable compliant, audit-ready applications on public rails.

Projects like Chainlink, RAILGUN, Aztec Network, and Zama are featured for pioneering privacy-preserving smart contracts that allow secure counterparties and business logic without sacrificing transparency or composability.

These advancements represent a leap for institutions balancing compliance mandates with the need for secure, programmable finance. “Privacy solutions are no longer theoretical — they're live and scaling in production,” Ethereum Foundation notes.Tokenization, Stablecoins, and Real-World Assets

Ethereum said it dominates the real-world asset (RWA) and stablecoin sectors, hosting over 75% of all tokenized RWAs and 60% of global stablecoin supply.

Institutions can now explore market infrastructure at institutions.ethereum.org/rwas-stablecoins, where tokenized treasuries and onchain credit platforms are reshaping capital markets.

From BlackRock and Securitize to Ondo Finance, Centrifuge, and Maple, major financial firms are deploying tokenized instruments that offer 24/7 settlement, transparency, and composability.

Stablecoins issued by Tether, Circle, PayPal, and Ethena Labs are also highlighted for their role in accelerating global onchain payments.Restaking, Layer-2s, and the Composable Financial Stack

The foundation said Ethereum's Layer-2 networks — including Linea, Starknet, Base, Scroll, and Unichain — now secure over $50 billion in value, offering the throughput and cost efficiency required for global-scale applications.

At the same time, staking and restaking protocols like Ether.fi, EigenLayer, Lido, RocketPool, and Symbiotic are enabling institutions to participate in Ethereum's security model while earning yield on staked ETH.

With 67% of DeFi's total value locked (TVL) and the deepest liquidity across any blockchain, Ethereum continues to lead as the settlement layer for institutional-grade decentralized finance.

The new Ethereum for Institutions portal is a living resource, continuously updated to feature ecosystem builders, regulatory innovations, and enterprise-grade integrations. 

Institutions can engage directly with the Ethereum Foundation's Enterprise Acceleration team via — joining a growing global movement to bring finance fully onchain.

Title: Binance Says Goodbye to 3 Altcoins: Double Collapse, One Unexpected Rebound
Description:
While KDA and PERP crash after Binance's delisting, FLM rallies | Credit: Veronica Cestari                        


Key Takeaways

Three altcoins just got the Binance axe, and the market's reaction couldn't be more dramatic.

Kadena (KDA) and Perpetual Protocol (PERP) experienced a significant decline, losing a substantial portion of their value within hours.

Flamingo (FLM) surprised everyone, swinging upward in a show of short-term strength.

What's behind this sudden split? Is FLM's rebound a fluke, or not? Let's evaluate each token.

Binance delists altcoins that consistently exhibit low trading volume, poor liquidity, and insufficient project development, as these assets no longer meet the exchange's quality standards.

In some cases, it delists assets due to regulatory or security risks, such as non-compliance and potential fraud, to protect user funds and maintain platform integrity.

Earlier today, Binance announced plans  to delist Kadena (KDA), with the move set to take effect on November 12.

The decision, while significant, may not come as a surprise to market observers.

Last week, the Kadena team confirmed its exit from the project, a revelation that triggered a sell-off and sent KDA's price tumbling.

Following Binance's delisting notice, Kadena's market value dropped another 25% today.

Interestingly, on the same day, Gate, another exchange, noted that it will continue to support  the project.

From a technical perspective, the daily chart shows that the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) has formed a bearish crossover.

With no demand in sight, KDA's price might reach a new all-time low below $0.045.

However, this trend might reverse if many other exchanges drum up support for Kadena. In that scenario, the altcoin might rise toward $0.20.

PERP, native to the decentralized perpetual futures DEX, Perpetual Protocol, was also one of the altcoins Binance delisted.

Following the recent development, PERP's price has declined by 14%. Although the altcoin remains at 76% of its record low, which reached 19 days ago, the technical structure still leans bearish.

On the daily chart, PERP continues to trade within a descending channel, indicating persistent downward pressure.

Meanwhile, the Awesome Oscillator (AO) has slipped into the negative region, confirming rising bearish momentum.

If this trend persists, PERP could fall below the channel's lower boundary, potentially declining toward $0.12.

However, if buying momentum returns and the price breaks above near-term resistance, this bearish outlook may be invalidated, opening the door for a rebound toward $0.28.

The last on Binance's delisting list is FLM, the native token of the decentralized finance (DeFi) platform Flamingo.

Interestingly, instead of plunging, FLM's price surged by 13.65% following the announcement, climbing to $0.023.

However, such rebounds after delisting news often carry significant risk.

On the daily chart, CCN's analysis shows that FLM has formed a bearish divergence, a warning signal that the rally may not be sustainable.

This divergence emerged as the Chaikin Money Flow (CMF) turned negative, despite a bullish price movement.

Additionally, the red line of the Supertrend indicator remains above Flamingo's price, reinforcing the bearish bias.

If sustained, downside pressure could return once the short-term euphoria fades. As such, FLM's price could slide to $0.013.

However, a surge in demand for the token could invalidate this bias. In that case, FLM's price might surge to $0.027.

Title: XRP Price Prediction Before FOMC Rate Cut: Breakout Imminent for Top Altcoins like $BEST?
Description:
Quick Facts:

$XRP is one of the best performers among heavy-cap cryptos this week.

For context, $BTC has surged 5% over the past seven days, while $ETH is up 4.5%. Considering the previous weeks' bloodbath, the trend paints an optimistic picture for the market, but their gains pale in comparison to $XRP's 9.45%.

The cross-border remittance token has managed a steady climb for most of the week, briefly touching $2.69 before retracing slightly. Keeping up with the spot market's energy, the derivatives market has also perked up, as open interest (OI) crosses $4.5B.

Multiple factors indicate that $XRP's recent surge might be short-lived. It could be a while before it reclaims its all-time high of $3.65, since the rise in open interest could swing either way.

For instance, the OI-weighted funding rate has declined, revealing that confidence in $XRP will be fragile in the absence of a significant broader market shift. Short positions likely anticipate another test of the key support level at $2.18.

The RSI (Relative Strength Index) is now at 51, while the current price is just slightly below the 50-day exponential moving average of 2.6852, further indicating that the recent rally is slowing down.

That partly explains the renewed activity in the derivatives market, which dropped to $3.49B on October 19 – its lowest point since late April.

Title: Telegram CEO unveils Cocoon, a decentralized AI compute network built on TON
Description:
Share this article

At Blockchain Life 2025, Telegram CEO Pavel Durov unveiled Cocoon, short for Confidential Compute Open Network, a decentralized infrastructure initiative combining blockchain, AI, and social media.

Durov said Cocoon will allow GPU owners to contribute computing power to the network and earn TON tokens in exchange, while developers access low-cost AI compute. The system is designed to ensure users can interact with AI features like summarization and message drafting without exposing private data to centralized providers.

Telegram itself will be the first major customer and largest promoter of the network, integrating Cocoon's capabilities into its mini-app and bot ecosystem. The project is scheduled to launch in November 2025, and applications are open to both hardware providers and developers.

Durov emphasized that Cocoon's transparent, market-driven design will make AI compute pricing competitive and censorship-resistant. He framed the initiative as part of Telegram's broader mission to protect user privacy and digital freedom amid growing centralization in global tech.

Title: Efficient ring signature for cross-chain data sharing in blockchain-enabled cold-chain logistics system
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Scientific Reports
volume 15, Article number: 37791 (2025)
            Cite this article


Blockchain-enabled cold-chain logistics system (BCCLS) has solved the centralized problem in traditional CCLS system. However, along with that different logistics entities establish their own distributed blockchain ledger, it brings new “data island” and privacy leakage problems for BCCLS. In this paper, a transaction ring signing model with multi-chain fusion (MCF) mechanism has been introduced first which helps achieve secure cross-chain data sharing. The MCF mechanism utilizes the relay chain technology to establish a cross-chain transaction platform among different chains. The transaction ring signing model establishes a ring signature mechanism for one cold-chain logistics product circulating in different institutions. Meanwhile, a ring signature (RS) scheme based on lattice assumption is proposed, which can improve the anti-quantum security of transaction ring signing model. This RS is constructed by lattice assumption which can anti-quantum attack security for cross-chain transaction in BCCLS. Then, the security proof shows that the RS scheme can achieve anonymity under full key exposure and unforgeability under insider attack. The efficiency comparison shows that the RS scheme is efficient than similar schemes, and the performance evaluation shows that the transaction ring signing model with MCF model is efficient and practical.

Nowadays, the cold-chain logistics system (CCLS) plays an essential role for cold-chain logistics data collection1. Especially with the emergency of blockchain technology, the distributed blockchain-enabled CCLS (BCCLS) draws much attention for solving the centralized problem in traditional CCLSs2. However, one piece of cold-chain logistics data generally needs many cold-chain logistics workers and devices to cooperate, which brings privacy leakage risk for the system user and cold-chain logistics data in BCCLS. Meanwhile, with the number increasing of chains in different cold-chain logistics institutions, new “data island” problem emerges again as the data structure, consensus algorithms, cryptographic algorithms are different in different chains.

Blockchain technology draws many attentions in recent years, which is utilized in many production and life areas as finance3, education4, medical5, logistics6, and so on. It gives a new sight for traditional centralized information systems to solve the centralized management and privacy leakage problems. Blockchain changes the storage form from centralization to distribution for cold-chain logistics data, and improves the traceability capability for frozen food by establishing an immutable distributed ledger2. Because of these revolutions, the consumers can view the food information of production, transportation, processing, etc., which can guarantee the food security7. There are many blockchain-enabled CCLS models or platforms have been introduced in recent years, such as Blockcoldchain, ClodBlocks, and so on8,9,10,11,12. However, these novel frameworks mainly focus on solving traditional centralized problems, which do not consider the cross-chain data-sharing problems.

The cross-chain technologies have drawn many attentions in the blockchain-enabled systems and applications. At present, four mainstream cross-chain schemes are notary mechanism, side chain/relay, hash lock and distributed private key control13. Among them, the notary public mechanism introduces a trusted third-party institution as the verifier and coordinator of cross-chain transactions14. After the transaction initiator initiates a transaction on the source chain, the notary verifies whether the transaction is valid by listening to the events on the source chain. After the verification is passed, the notary public notifies the target chain to perform corresponding operations. The side chain/relay chain is more expensive and less efficient, because in this mode, the transaction needs to wait for the chain to determine that the rollback will not occur before confirming15,16,17,18. Hash locking ensures the atomicity of cross-chain asset exchange, but usually can only be used for cross-chain asset exchange, but cannot realize cross-chain transfer of assets or other forms of interaction19. Distributed private key control also needs to wait for source chain transactions to be connected, and it is difficult to develop20. In addition, there are also some other cross-chain protocols, such as cross-consensus message (XCM) in Polkadot21, and inter-blockchain communication (IBC) in Cosmos22. These two protocols mainly set a format for cross-chain transaction, which can support the cross-chain network to unify the format of message in heterogeneous blockchain-based systems. For one cold-chain product, it will pass many logistics institutions from the production to consumption, such as feeding, transport, testing, processing, selling, and buying. The relay chain can help to establish cross-chain data-sharing platform among different chains in different cold-chain logistics institutions, and this paper plans to construct an MCF model to support the cross-chain logistics data-sharing in BCCLS.

As the cold-chain logistics data general contains the sensitive information about the logistics workers and institutions, which are vulnerable to the leakage risk when they are transmitted among the different cold-chain logistics workers and devices. To seek the privacy protection algorithm for cross-chain transaction in BCCLS is the essential work. In general, the cryptographic algorithms are the effective methods to protection system data and user privacy in current information systems. Digital signature gives a proof for the transaction validity, and the signer cannot deny a valid signature sign by himself. It has been developed with many kinds, such as blind signature23, proxy signature24, ring signature25, group signature26, undeniable signature27, designated verifier signature28, etc., which play the different roles in different situations. Meanwhile, the difficult mathematical problems are the bases for these signature schemes. Common RSA and elliptic curve encryption protocols are based on large integer factorization problem and discrete logarithm problem respectively29,30. Recently, the post-quantum encryption based on lattice, hash, and multivariate-quadratic-equations has drawn many attentions as it can resist the quantum attack31,32,33,34,35. With the rapid developments of quantum computer and quantum computing, the post-quantum encryption becomes more and more popular and practical for information systems. Some ring signature schemes with lattice assumption have been introduced in recent years, which are constructed with different lattice assumptions and applied in different areas36,37. For the cold-chain logistics data sharing in BCCLS, the ring signature is more suitable to establish a secure verification mechanism among many different cold-chain logistics workers and devices.

This paper focuses on the “data island” and privacy leakage problems in BCCLS, and introduces a transaction ring signing model with multi-chain fusion mechanism firstly. Then, to improve the anti-quantum security of transaction ring signing model, a lattice-based ring signature (RS) scheme is designed. The main contributions are shown in the following:

A multi-chain fusion mechanism has been introduced first, which utilize rely chain to establish secure cross-chain logistics data sharing channel through BCCLS.

A transaction ring signing model has been proposed, which provides a ring verification mechanism between different cold chain logistics entities. This model can guarantee the privacy security in the cross-chain logistics data sharing processes in BCCLS.

A lattice-based ring signature (RS) scheme is designed, which supports the transaction ring signing model for multi-chain fusion mechanism. This scheme also provides the anti-quantum attack security for cold-chain logistics data.

The security proofs of anonymity and unforgeability have been presented, which show the proposed RS is secure. The performance evaluations have been given to state the efficiency and practical of the proposed model and RS scheme.

The organizations are as follows: Sect. 2 gives some related work, Sect. 3 introduces the multi-chain fusion mechanism and transaction ring signing model, Sect. 4 proposes a new RS scheme, Sect. 5 shows the security proof and analysis, Sect. 6 presents the efficiency comparison and performance, and Sect. 7 concludes.

This section presents some reviews about two main themes of the blockchain methods for CCLS and digital signature scheme for privacy-preserving.

Blockchain servers as a distributed ledger which helps the cold-chain logistics to establish cross-institution data-sharing platform. Some BCCLSs have been proposed in recent years, which establish many interesting frameworks and models. Kim et al. established a cold chain system with blockchain technology for blood supplement, which provided a safe and traceable record sheet8. Mendoca et al. proposed a blockchain-based vaccine cold chain network called Blockcoldchain, which established a traceability mechanism to protect the security of transportation process9. Menon et al. introduced a ClodBlocks which utilized blockchain and IoT to guarantee the quality security for clod chain logistics data10. Hu gave a BCCLS for agricultural products, which provided a record of the whole process11. Ni et al. presented a blockchain platform for maritime logistics and optimized the latency, send rate and throughput with a consensus algorithm of proof of concept12. With more and more different chains have been constructed in different cold-chain logistics institutions, these BCCLSs cannot satisfy the cross-chain demands. Xiong et al. proposed a notary group-based cross-chain interaction model which utilized the notary election mechanism and margin pool to achieve cross-chain transaction among different blockchains14. Kong et al. applied the relay chain to construct a heterogeneous adaptive routing protocol, which could achieve load balancing and high energy efficiency15. Li et al.16 constructed a relay chain-based cross-chain platform for IoMT system, and they also proposed a lattice-based designated verifier signature scheme to protect the privacy in cross-chain transaction. Jiang et al.17 introduced a multi-chain fusion model with relay chain, which also applied the cross-chain gateway and IBC to achieve cross-chain interaction and communication for IoMT. Zhang et al.18 formed a DeCross framework with relay chain for industrial Internet of things, which established a cross-chain consensus protocol based on a parallel processing workflow prototype. Sun et al. presented a cross-chain service scheme with the notary mechanism and hash-locking, which aggregate these cross-chain technologies together solve data island problem and evil attack19. Xu et al. designed an access control scheme for distributed Internet of things, and they also applied a symmetric encryption algorithm to protect privacy security20. These researches give a new sight for solving the new “data island” problem in BCCLS, and the cross-chain technologies also can be used to achieve cross-chain data sharing between different clod-chain logistics institutions with different chains.

Digital signature serves as essential part of the blockchain transaction, which plays the role in the processes of transaction legality verification and record traceability. There are many different kinds of signature schemes have been applied in different areas for privacy-preserving. Gao et al. proposed a blind signature for Internet of vehicle, which could blind the image information in the data transmission process23. Wang et al. introduced a proxy signature scheme based on lattice assumption, which improved the anti-quantum security for Internet of things24. Zhang et al. presented a ring signature for the microgrid day-ahead market, which utilized double auction algorithm to achieve peer-to-peer payment25. Tang et al. designed an event-oriented linkable group signature scheme with lattice assumption which had more flexibility in relation to the signature control26. Mittal et al. proposed an undeniable signature scheme based on inverse computation and discrete logarithm problems, which could resist the impersonation attack27. Deng et al. designated verifier signature scheme for smart grids, and this signature scheme could protect the privacy security of both transaction parts as that only the designated user could verify the signature28. These former signature schemes cannot resist the quantum attacks.

Some post-quantum digital signatures are proposed. Li et al.31 proposed presented an undeniable signature scheme for E-voting system, which was constructed with the Fiat–Shamir signature framework. Xu et al.32 utilized the nested hash coding to construct a post-quantum encryption algorithm for IoT systems, and it also applied the random repetition coding to resist passive eavesdropping attacks. Lyubashevsky et al.34 proposed a CRYSTALS-Dilithium algorithm based on parameter set, hash function, and polynomial function to guarantee the security and performance against the quantum attacks. Prest et al.35 introduced a Falcon algorithm, which has anti-quantum security under the hardness of SIS problem on lattice. Xie et al.36 applied the lattice assumption to construct a blind ring signature scheme, which could improve the privacy security in blockchain-based transaction systems. Dong et al.37 designed a certificateless ring signature with lattice theory, which utilized SIS problem to ensure the anti-quantum property. For the privacy-preserving in BCCLS, there needs to provide transaction signature with different operators in different cold-chain logistics institutions for one product, and these former signature schemes are not suitable for this situation. This paper plans to establish a privacy-preserving framework with a lattice-based RS scheme for BCCLS.

Facing with new “data island” and privacy leakage problems in BCCLS, a transaction ring signature model with MCF mechanism has been presented in this section. The following sections first describe the relay chain-based MCF mechanism, and then present the detailed descriptions of the transaction ring signature model.

There are four main parts in this MCF mechanism, as: child chain, parent chain, fusion ledger, and cross-chain transaction. The simple processes are shown in Fig. 1, and details of these parts are given blow.

Multi-chain fusion mechanism.

Child chain: This kind of chain contains the chains of feeding (BCCLS 0), transport (BCCLS 1), testing (BCCLS 2), processing (BCCLS 3), selling (BCCLS 4), and buying phases (BCCLS n). As different parties in BCCLS have different functions, they generally establish different kinds of blockchain ledgers with public, consortium, or private blockchain technologies. This is the reason why the new “data island” problem is emerged again. How to destroy the difference limitations of the data structure, consensus algorithm, cryptographic protocol is first problem to solve. Meanwhile, the privacy security, data integrity, and interoperability are some main items which should been taken more considerations. Then, every child chain stores its own transaction records and it also participants the transaction processing in parent chain. It keeps its own operational activities with the general blockchain mechanism, and it does not need to synchronize other unrelated transaction information, which can significantly reduce the ledger bloat.

Parent chain: This is a relay chain which can help to establish a cross-chain transaction channel between different child chains. Through this relay chain, different child chains can connect with each other to initialize cross-chain transactions. It solves the data integrity and interoperability for cross-chain transactions in BCCLS, and utilizes the ring signature (show in Sect. 4) to guarantee the privacy security of cross-chain transaction. Here, a message exchanging protocol is utilized to solve the difference limitations, such as the differences of data structure, consensus protocol, and cryptographic algorithm. Meanwhile, a RS scheme is proposed to support the following transaction ring verification model. This RS scheme reduces the signing burdens as that a ring member can represent the ring group to perform sign operation, and guarantees the signer's anonymity as that no one can know the real signer unless opening the signature. Then, this parent chain mainly stores the cross-chain transactions, which does not record the transactions in child chains. It mainly focuses on the cross-chain issues when some cross-chain transaction needs have been occurred.

Fusion ledger: Firstly, this ledger serves as the public list for BCCLS, which records the cross-chain transactions created by cold-chain logistics parties in different child chains. It does not change the record form in child chains, and constructs a new ledger with unified form for cross-chain transaction in relay chain. Secondly, this ledger is maintained by the selected representatives from the child chains, and utilizes the consensus algorithms of PoS, DPoS to achieve network-wide consistency. Here, the consensus mechanism can support the MCF model as the child chains complete to serve as the system maintainer, which can avoid the problem of inconsistent ledger caused by a malicious child chain. This multi-chain competitive mechanism can promote the cross-chain transaction achievement and improve the transaction verification efficiency. Thirdly, like the transaction verification mechanism in generally blockchain system, the cross-chain transactions also need to be packaged, broadcasted, verified, and linked to the main ledger. As the transactions in this fusion ledger are immutable, which can provide the evidences for cross-chain transactions when there is a dispute.

Cross-chain transaction: The cross-chain transaction is the main parts for the MCF mechanism in BCCLS. It supports the cross-chain information exchanging between different users in different child chains. To the difference of data structure in heterogeneous BCCLS, the XCM and IBC ca. be used for unifying the message format. In this cross-chain transaction, both users' transaction addresses, signatures, timestamp, and other related information are inserted. For one cold-chain product, it will pass many logistics institutions with many workers, and this cross-chain transaction also be signed by these related workers. This transaction ring verification model (show in Sect. 3.2) utilizes a ring signature scheme to construct multi-party signature verification mechanism, which can guarantee the transaction traceability for cold-chain product disputes.

This MCF model helps to establish a secure cold-chain logistics data exchange mechanism among different chains in different logistics institutions. Different from the traditional blockchain structure, this MCF helps to construct a new cross-chain data sharing mechanism. It establishes a bridge among heterogeneous blockchain-based BCCLSs. Here, the relay chain acts the data and value exchange bridge, breaks the difficult limitation of data interoperability, and guarantees the immutability of cross-chain transactions. This model promotes the cross-chain data-sharing and improves the value play of cold-chain logistics data. Meanwhile, to protect the privacy of cold-chain logistics data and system users, a transaction ring signing model is needed as there are many logistics institutions participating in the cold-chain product transportation processes. The next section shows the detailed descriptions of this model.

The transaction ring verification model mainly contains four parts: Logistics data generation, Transaction ring signature, Transaction construction, and Distributed accounting. The simple processes are shown in Fig. 2, and details of these parts are given blow.

The transaction ring verification model.

Logistics data generation: For the frozen foods, such as meat, fruit, seafood, they will go through the processes of feeding, transport, testing, processing, selling, and buying from the production to consumption. Supporting by the technologies of Internet of things and RFID, BIoMT systems collect these data generated by these processes. Meanwhile, the blockchain ledger takes responsibility for the storage and recordation of the logistics data and processing records which are the essential evidences for secure frozen food management.

Transaction ring signature: These different doctor's processes relate to many medical workers in different departments. All of these workers take responsibility for the generation these medical data, so they must make a signature on them. Meanwhile, a ring signature scheme has been applied in this part. This signature scheme only needs one member to sign these medical data by representing the group, and the verification process can derive that this signature is generated by this group. It cannot confirm which member signs this signature, which can well guarantee the user privacy of the signer. Here, the related operators all need to sign on this cross-chain data sharing transaction with their own \((pk,sk)\) when the cold chain goods are transmitted through different logistics institutions. This RS plays a role of the transaction verifier to ensure the data integrity, reliability, and privacy security.

Transaction construction: After these medical data have been signed by the worker group, they will be packaged into a transaction and uploaded to BCCLS network for verification. Then, the mining nodes verify this transaction according the system consensus mechanism. Meanwhile, the IBC protocol is inserted into this cross-chain transaction, which can help to unify the data structure from different child chains. Only passing these verifications, this transaction can be packaged into a block and waits for the distributed accounting.

Distributed accounting: The verified transactions are packaged into a temporary block, and this block will attach to the longest chain fusion ledger in BCCLS system. Next, the newly transactions are also broadcasted to the whole network. Once this process is completed, these transactions become immutable records.

This transaction ring verification model utilizes the ring signature protocol to protect the privacy security, and establishes ring verification mechanism for cross-chain transactions among different BCCLSs. Meanwhile, this model can protect the signer's anonymity as there are no trust center and group establishment procedure. It helps different logistics workers to construct a ring signature protection mechanism in relation to one cross-chain logistics product. This ring signature mechanism also provides traceability mechanism when the dispute incidents occur.

(Lattice)38: Let \(V=[{v_1}| \cdots |{v_m}] \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{{r*m}}\) be linearly independent vectors in \({\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{r}\)and q be a prime, \(\Lambda (V)=\{ z \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{r}|z=Vx\bmod q,x \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{m}\}\) is the r-dimensional lattice to vector V.

The security of NTRU-based protocol is due to the distribution of \((a,z)\) is pseudo-random in \(\Re _{q}^{2}\) and the definition of NTRU Lattice is given below.

(NTRU Lattice)39: For a message V, the NTRU cryptosystem outputs a polynomial \(z=2(ar+e)+\mu\) in \({\Re _q}\) with \(\{ 0,1\}\) coefficients, by random selecting two short vectors \(r,e \in {\Re _q}({\Re _q}={\mathbb{Z}}[x]/({x^n}+1))\).

The short integer problem (\(SIS\)) is a more important lattice assumption for lattice cryptosystem, which was first presented by Ajtai40. The essence of this problem is to find a series of short nontrivial integer form a certain large finite additive group, and the sum of these uniformly random elements is zero. The proposed RS is mainly based on \(SIS\) problem, and the definition of \(SIS\) in the ring are \(\Re\) presented as following.

(\(\Re - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\)problem): By randomly choosing \(A \in \Re _{q}^{{n \times m}}\) according to the distribution k, there exists a non-zero \(v \in \Re _{q}^{m}\) which satisfies \(Av=0\) and \({\left\| v \right\|_2} \leqslant \beta\). Here, is \({\Re _q}\) the quotient ring \(\Re /(q\Re )\).

Gaussian Distribution41: The general Gaussian distribution for \(x \in \Re\) is defined as \({\rho _{c,\sigma }}(x)=\exp (\frac{{ - {{\left\| {x - c} \right\|}^2}}}{{2{\sigma ^2}}})\), where \(\sigma \in \Re\) is the standard deviation and \(c \in \Re\) is the center.

Note that, the Gaussian distribution can be simply written as \({\rho _\sigma }(x)\) when the center c is 0. Meanwhile, the discrete Gaussian distribution over \({\mathbb{Z}}\) is defined as \({D_\sigma }(x)={\rho _\sigma }(x)/{\rho _\sigma }(z)\) with center 0, and written as \(D_{\sigma }^{m}(x)={\rho _\sigma }(x)/{\rho _\sigma }{(z)^m}\) over \({{\mathbb{Z}}^m}\). Next, the discrete Gaussian is defined as follows.

(Discrete Gaussian)41: The function \({\rho _{c,\sigma }}(x):{\Re ^n} \to (0,1]\) of n-dimensional Gaussian with the center c can be described as: \({\rho _{c,\sigma }}(x)\mathop =\limits^{\Delta } \exp (\frac{{ - {{\left\| {x - c} \right\|}^2}}}{{2{\sigma ^2}}})\).

With the security parameter n, a RS is composed of three probabilistic polynomial time algorithms as follows.

KeyGen (\({1^n}\)): Given n, this step derives the public and private key pairs \((p{k_i},s{k_i})\) for every ring user.

Sign \((p{k_1},p{k_2},...,p{k_l},s{k_a},m)\): For a message m, a signer generates a signature e with all ring users' public key \((p{k_1},p{k_2},...,p{k_l})\) and the signer's private key \(s{k_a}\).

Verify\((e,p{k_a},m)\): The verifier verifies \(e'{\text{s}}\) legality with the signer's public key \(p{k_a}\), and outputs the results.

For a digital signature scheme, the security proof in random oracle model is general method to prove the scheme security. This security model is composed of two participants of a challenger C and an adversary A, which establishes a query-respond game between these two participants and utilizes proof by contradiction to prove the security of RS security. First and formost, a hypothesis that A has ability to forge a valid signature with some key information is preset. Detailed descriptions are as follows.

Initialize: Given the system parameters, C initializes the query-respond game with A.

Hash query: A queries on the hash algorithm for enough times without the target messge \({m^*}\), by choosing the ring users' public keys \(p{k_i}\).

Secret key query: A queries on the user's private key \(s{k_i}\) in relation to the user's public key \(p{k_i}\) for enough times without the target user's private key \(sk_{i}^{*}\).

Signature query: A queries on the sign algorithm in relation to the user \(p{k_i}\) for enough times without the target messge \({m^*}\).

Forge: A forges a valid signature \((e,{m^*})\) in relation to the target message \({m^*}\), and sends to C.

Challenge: A utilizes the query-respond results of the former three algorithms and the forged signature \((e,{m^*})\) to derives the signature \((e^{\prime},{m^*})\) for the target message \({m^*}\). Then, A attempts to derive a solution for the \({\mathbb{Z}} - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\) instance with these two valid signatures by using Forking lemma.

Analyze: Under current classical computational conditions, the lattice assumption \({\mathbb{Z}} - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\) cannot be solved. By the proof by contradiction, the former hypothesis is invalid, and the RS is secure.

This security model is defined for RS scheme. From this query-respond game, C can solve the hard problem with the query results and forged signature. But this is improssible with current computation condition. So this security proof has proved that a secure RS can capture the security properities of anonymity, unforgeability, and undeniable.

This RS scheme can establish a transaction ring verification mechanism to protect the cross-chain logistics data sharing security and users' privacy security. It is constructed with the lattice assumption \(\Re - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\) with a uniform distribution κ. Here, to simplify the work way, this RS scheme reduces \(\Re ={\mathbb{Z}}\) and executes in rings \(\Re ={\mathbb{Z}}[x]/({x^n}+1)\) with the same hardness assumption \({\mathbb{Z}} - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\)40. This RS generally contains the algorithms of KeyGen., Ring Sign, and Ring Verify, and the simple processes are described as shown in Fig. 3. In addition, it also utilizes the bimodal Gaussian distribution to improve the performance efficiency. Next are the detailed descriptions.

Ring signing process.

Key Gen.: The system parameters \(n,m,q,\kappa ,\sigma\) are preset with the security parameter \(\kappa\) and \(m=O(n\log q)\). Next, the public and private keys are derived as shown in Algorithm 1.

Key Gen.

Ring Sign: Assume the ring member k with \(({A_k},{S_k})\) represents to sign message \(\mu\).

Ring Sign.

Ring Verify: The ring signature \((e,c)\) can be verified by ring member \(k's\) public key \({A_k}\). Here, \(\left\| e \right\|>T\) with the conditions of \(T=\eta \sqrt m {\sigma _1}\), and \(\eta\) can be verified with probability \(1 - {2^{ - \kappa }}\) for the security parameter \(\kappa\) (in practice \(\eta \in [1.1,1.4]\)).

Ring Verify.

After this transaction signature passes the verification, it will be uploaded to the blockchain for verification and package. When this transaction passes the blockchain verification, it will become an unalterable record in the blockchain ledger. In this RS scheme, one of the ring group users performs the signing process, and nobody can know which one user is the real signer. This mechanism can guarantee the anonymity of real ring singing user. Meanwhile, it can verify the validity of ring signature and trace the real signer by opening the signature when some disputes occur. This RS scheme can well support the privacy protection in cross-chain data sharing process in BCCLS.

The signature \((e,c)\) should satisfy three conditions. First is\(\left\| e \right\|<{T_1}\), as \({T_1}\) is defined in the Ring Verify algorithm. Second is \({\left\| e \right\|_\infty }<q/4\), as this condition is restricted system security reason. Third is \(c \leftarrow H({A_k}e+qcmod2q,\mu )\), as that it is based on the following Eq. (1) holds.

Security proof of the anonymity and unforgeability have been given in the following two subsections.

For the RS's anonymity, the case of full key exposure should be taken into consideration, and detailed proof processes are shown in the following.

Based on the hardness of lattice assumption \(\Re - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\), this RS can achieve anonymity under full key exposure.

Suppose there exists an adaptive adversary A, who performs attack on the RS's anonymity under full key exposure. Then, there exists a challenger who can execute a query-respond game with A to solve SIS problem a polynomial time algorithm C.

First and foremost, parameters \(n,m,q,\kappa ,\sigma\) are given. C performs the Key Gen. with \({q_E}\) times to derive ring group members' public keys \({A_i} \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{{2q}}^{{n*m}},\;(i=1,2,...,l)\) and the corresponding secret keys \({S_i} \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{{2q}}^{{m*n}}\). Here, \({R_i}=\{ 1,2,...,{q_E}\}\)is the ring of these \({q_E}\) members. C initializes an empty list \(lis{t_K}\)storing \(\left\langle {i,{A_i},{S_i}} \right\rangle\), and then sends the public key set \(\{ {A_1},{A_2}, \ldots ,{A_l}\}\) to A.

Hquery: C initializes an empty list \(lis{t_H}\)storing \(\left\langle {{R_i},{u_j},{c_{ij}}} \right\rangle\). Upon receiving a  Hquery from A, C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{R_i},{u_j},{c_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_H}\) and returns \({c_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, he randomly selects \({y_1},{y_2} \leftarrow D_{\sigma }^{m}\) at random and computes \({c_{ij}} \leftarrow H((\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{A_k}{y_2}mod2q,{\mu _j})\). Then, he adds \({c_{ij}}\) to \(lis{t_H}\), and returns it to A.

For member \({i_1}'s\) private key query, C checks list \(lis{t_K}\) and returns \({S_i}\) back to A.

For member \({i_1}'s\)sign query on signature \(\left\langle {k,{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\), C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{i_1},{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_S}\) and returns \({e_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, C first performs H query to obtain \({c_{ij}}\), and randomly selects \(b \in \{ 0,1\}\) to compute the signature \({e_{ij}}\) by \({e_{ij}} \leftarrow A_{{{i_1}}}^{{ - 1}}(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{y_2}+{( - 1)^b}{S_{{i_1}}}c\). Then, he adds \(({e_{ij}},{c_{ij}})\) to \(lis{t_S}\), returns it back to A.

Forge phase: A launches a challenge \(\left\langle {{k_0},{k_1},{R^*},{u^*}} \right\rangle\), where ring \({R^*}\) signs on the target message \({u^*}\). \({k_0}\) and \({k_1}\) are two members of ring \({R^*}\). C chooses \({t^*} \in \{ 0,1\}\), checks the \(\left\langle {{R^*},{u^*},{c^*}} \right\rangle\) in list \(lis{t_H}\), and derives the associated secret “trapdoor” \({S_{{R^*}}}\) with relation to \({A_{{R^*}}}\). Then, he computes a challenge signature \({e_{ij}}\), and returns it to A. Next, A gives his guess \(t^{\prime} \in \{ 0,1\}\).

It can easily derive that the statistical distance of \({e_{{k_0}}}'s,{e_{{k_1}}}'s\) distribution and \(D_{\sigma }^{m}\) is negligible. Therefore, the statistical distance of \({e_{{k_0}}}\) and \({e_{{k_1}}}\) is also negligible. This derives that A guesses 0 or 1 with the same probability. So, the proposed RS scheme has anonymity under full key exposure.

For the RS's unforgeability, the case of insider attack should be taken into consideration.

Based on the hardness of lattice assumption \(\Re - SIS_{{q,n,m,\beta }}^{\kappa }\), this RS can achieve unforgeability under insider attack.

Assume there exists an adaptive adversary A, who performs attack on the RS's unforgeability under insider attack. Then, there exists a challenger who can execute a query-respond game with A to solve SIS problem by a polynomial time algorithm C.

First and foremost, parameters \(n,m,q,\kappa ,\sigma\) are given. C selects \(l \in \left[ {{q_E}} \right]\) as the number of challenge ring member. He obtains a SIS instance \({A_{{R_t}}} \in Z_{q}^{{n \times lm}}\) and divides this \(n \times lm\) matrix into l matrixes with \(n \times m\). Note that \({A_{{R_t}}}=[{A_{1*}}{A_{2*}} \cdots {A_{l*}}]\), where \({A_{{i^{st}}}} \in Z_{q}^{{n \times m}}\). C selects \({t_i} \in \left[ {{q_E}} \right],i \in \{ 1,2, \cdots ,l\}\), and sets \({R_t}=\{ {t_1},{t_2}, \cdots ,{t_l}\}\). Then, C servers the sub-matrix \({A_{i*}}\) as the public key of ring \({R_t}\) member. Therefore, \({A_{ti}}={A_{i*}}\) for the member in ring \({R_t}\). For the \({q_E} - l\) ring member out of \({R_t}\), C performs the Key Gen. with \({q_E}\) times to derive ring group members' public keys \({A_i} \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{{2q}}^{{n*m}},\;(i=1,2,...,l)\) and the corresponding secret keys \({S_i} \in {\mathbb{Z}}_{{2q}}^{{m*n}}\). Here, \(R=\{ 1,2,...,{q_E}\}\)is the ring of these \({q_E}\) members. C initializes an empty list \(lis{t_K}\)storing \(\left\langle {i,{A_i},{S_i}} \right\rangle\), and then sends the public key set \(\{ {A_1},{A_2}, \ldots ,{A_{{q_E}}}\}\) to A.

Hquery: C initializes an empty list \(lis{t_H}\)storing \(\left\langle {{R_i},{u_j},{c_{ij}}} \right\rangle\). Upon receiving a Hquery from A, C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{R_i},{u_j},{c_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_H}\) and returns \({c_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, he randomly selects \({y_1},{y_2} \leftarrow D_{\sigma }^{m}\) at random and computes \({c_{ij}} \leftarrow H((\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{A_k}{y_2}mod2q,{\mu _j})\). Then, he adds \({c_{ij}}\) to \(lis{t_H}\), and returns it to A.

For member \({i_1} \notin {R_t}\) private key query, C checks list \(lis{t_K}\) for \(\left\langle {{i_1},{A_{{i_1}}},{S_{{i_1}}}} \right\rangle\) and returns \({S_i}\) back to A. Otherwise, abort.

For member \({i_1}'s\)sign query on signature \(\left\langle {{i_1},{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\), there exist three cases which should be taken into consideration.

If \({R_i}={R_t}\), C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{i_1},{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_S}\) and returns \({e_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, C first performs Hquery to obtain \({c_{ij}}\), and randomly selects \(b \in \{ 0,1\}\) to compute the signature \({e_{ij}}\) by \({e_i} \leftarrow A_{k}^{{ - 1}}(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{y_2}+{( - 1)^b}{S_k}c\). Then, he adds \(({e_i},{c_{ij}})\) to \(lis{t_S}\), returns it back to A.

If \({R_i} \ne {R_t}\) and \({i_1} \in {R_i} - {R_t}\), the \(\left\langle {{i_1},{A_{{i_1}}},{S_{{i_1}}}} \right\rangle\) exists in list \(lis{t_K}\). C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{i_1},{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_S}\) and returns \({e_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, C first performs Hquery to obtain \({c_{ij}}\). Then, he derives the associated secret “trapdoor” \({S_{{R_i}}}\) with relation to \({A_{{R_i}}}\), and randomly selects \(b \in \{ 0,1\}\) to compute the signature \({e_{ij}}\) by \({e_{ij}} \leftarrow A_{{{R_i}}}^{{ - 1}}(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{y_2}+{( - 1)^b}{S_{{R_i}}}{c_{ij}}\). Then, he adds \(({e_i},{c_{ij}})\) to \(lis{t_S}\), returns it back to A.

If \({R_i} \ne {R_t}\) and \({i_1} \in {R_i} \cap {R_t}\), the \(\left\langle {{i_1},{A_{{i_1}}},{S_{{i_1}}}} \right\rangle\) does not exist in list \(lis{t_K}\). C first checks the query history. If this query already exists, C finds the storing \(\left\langle {{i_1},{R_i},{u_j},{e_{ij}}} \right\rangle\) on \(lis{t_S}\) and returns \({e_{ij}}\) back. Otherwise, C first finds a \({i_2} \in {R_i} \cap {R_t}\) as the \(\left\langle {{i_2},{A_{{i_2}}},{S_{{i_2}}}} \right\rangle\) exists in list \(lis{t_K}\). Then, he derives the associated secret “trapdoor” \({S_{{R_i}}}\) with relation to \({A_{{R_i}}}\), performs H query to obtain \({c_{ij}}\), and randomly selects \(b \in \{ 0,1\}\) to compute the signature \({e_{ij}}\) by \({e_{ij}} \leftarrow A_{{{R_i}}}^{{ - 1}}(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}} ){y_1}+{y_2}+{( - 1)^b}{S_{{R_i}}}{c_{ij}}\). Then, he adds \(({e_{ij}},{c_{ij}})\) to \(lis{t_S}\), returns it back to A.

Suppose ε represents the probability that A outputs a legitimate signature. Here, the probability that C successfully solve the SIS instance is mainly depended on the private key query phase and challenge phase. As there are l ring member in R, the probability of successfully private key query for \(i \notin {R_t}\) is \(1 - 1/{q_E}\), and the probability of successfully challenge for \({R^*}={R_t}\) is \(1/C_{{{q_E}}}^{l}\). Therefore, the probability that challenger C successfully solve the SIS instance is at least \(\varepsilon \left( {1 - 1/{q_E}} \right)/C_{{{q_E}}}^{l}\). Here, with the query times \({q_E}\) increasing, the success probability becomes more negligible. So, the proposed RS scheme has unforgeability under insider attack.

For this RS scheme, one ring member can represent the ring group to sign the message, and the ring group users cannot deny this signature. As in the signature generation process, all the public keys of ring members are constructed by \(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}}\). In the one hand, this mechanism guarantees that the signer is authorized by the ring group, and the ring signature is approved by all the ring group members. In the other hand, this construction provides a signature traceability mechanism as it can quickly find the target user once the medical disputes occur. This security property can protect the user privacy as it cannot know which member of the real signer is, and also provide a secure traceability mechanism for the cold-chain logistics data sharing in the BCCLS.

Therefore, the proposed RS scheme can satisfy the security properties of correctness, anonymity, unforgeability, and undeniable. This RS scheme supports the transaction ring signing model and establishes a ring signature mechanism for one cold-chain logistics product circulating in different institutions. In addition, this RS scheme improves the cross-chain transactions security with the multi-chain fusion mechanism in the BCCLS. The fusion ledger protects the immutability of the cold-chain logistics data and provides a mechanism for traceability of the cross-chain data processing.

To compare the efficiency of this proposed RS scheme, three similar RS schemes have been selected. First, the system parameters \(n,m,q,\sigma\) in these schemes are unified, and the parameter k in41 is set as \(k=0.96n\). Then, three items of the public key size \(pk\), private key size \(sk\), and signature size are considered, and the comparison results are listed in the following Table 1. As for the scheme in Ref.36, the key size of these three items will increase with the increasing of message length l. For the scheme in Ref.37, these three items are all bigger than that in this RS scheme. Therefore, this RS scheme is efficient than similar schemes.

Key size comparison with 192-bit security level.

Meanwhile, the performance evaluation of this RS comparing with similar schemes are executed. Here, the parameters are set as \(n=1024,q={2^{27}}\) with 192-bit security level, \(m=8323\) for 192-bit which satisfies \(m \geqslant n\left\lceil {\log q} \right\rceil\), the message length is preset to \(l=10\), and \(\sigma ={2^{30}}\). The more intuitive comparison results are show in the following Fig. 4. The sizes of public key \(pk\) and private key \(sk\) are more space saving, and the signature size is almost 1/5 of that in Ref36.

Then, the time consumption of the proposed RS scheme has been performed and compared with these two related references. The comparison results are shown in Table 2. Here, TTrap, TSam, TMul, and TH represent the times consumption of Trapdoor, Gaussian Sample, Matrix Multiplication, and Hash algorithms, respectively. These performance results show that this RS scheme has certain advantage about the time consumption than similar schemes. Meanwhile, the results are shown in Fig. 5 with more intuitive form. Here, the time consumption of algorithms TTrap, TSam, TMul, and TH are set as 1.5 ms, 1 ms, 0.1ms, and 0.8 ms respectively, which is set according to the standard experiment environment. Therefore, the cross-chain data sharing transactions will more efficient with more low time consumption algorithms.

Time consumption performance.

In addition, along with the logistics link increasing, the key size and time consumption have no changes. As shown in Tables 1 and 2, the system indexes do not increase with the ring users increasing. Meanwhile, in the ring singing phase, the ring users' public keys are aggregated together with \(\sum\limits_{{i=1}}^{l} {{A_i}}\), and this continuous addition calculation mode cannot change the dimensionality of the public keys. So, it cannot increase the computational complexity and the time consumption of this RS scheme. Therefore, this RS scheme can well support the ring users update and has favorable scalability.

Transaction throughput and latency are two main factors for cross-chain transaction in BCCLS. This paper executes the cross-chain transaction in the Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum environment, and selects a single-chain model for comparison with 1000 pieces of transactions. The performance environment is on a Windows 11 desktop with Intel® Core™ i7-9700p 3.0 GHz and 16G RAM. This is a simulation environment close to reality. The comparisons for transaction throughput and latency for these two models are shown in Figs. 6 and 7, respectively. Here, the “H” and “E” represent the Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum environment respectively. In these two figures, the results show that the indexes of transaction throughput and latency in cross-chain model are small weak than that in single-chain model. But it still shows that the cross-chain transaction model is practical for data sharing in different cold-chain logistics institutions as the differences between these two models are small. Meanwhile, the transaction throughput performed in Hyperledger Fabric is bigger than that in Ethereum, and the transaction latency performed in Hyperledger Fabric is smaller than that in Ethereum. This is because of that Hyperledger Fabric is for enterprise application with consortium blockchain, and the Ethereum is for general users with public blockchain. So the Hyperledger Fabric is more suitable for cross-chain data sharing in BCCLSs. Then, with the institution chains number increasing, the cross-chain data sharing demands are also increasing, and these small differences will be ignored with technology development.

Transaction throughput comparison.

Transaction latency comparison.

With the same performance evaluation environment, the transaction simulations with different transaction number are executed. The comparison results are shown in the following Figs. 8 and 9. With the transaction number increasing, the transaction throughput increases slowly with relation to the items of “CreateAccount” and “Query”, and the throughput of “Transaction” keeps stable no matter the transaction number increasing. For the transaction latency, the items of “Query” and “Transaction” increase slowly, but the item of “CreateAccount” increases a lit quickly. This phenomenon is emerged with two reasons: one is that some new accounts have been registered, and the other is that many new cross-chain transaction addresses are generated. In addition, the stable phenomenon also shows the efficiency and practical of the proposed cross-chain model, which brings a more promising application for the proposed model and RS algorithm in BCCLS.

Transaction throughput with number increasing.

Transaction latency comparison with number increasing.

Meanwhile, the CUP and RAM usage are monitored when the cross-chain transactions execute in BCCLS. The results are shown in Fig. 10. With the transaction number increasing, the use condition of CUP and RAM keep a slow growth. It indicates that the proposed MCF model and RS scheme is not resource consumption, and it can well support the cross-chain data sharing transaction among different BCCLSs.

CPU and RAM use condition with transaction execution.

Here, note that the above data analyses are all the average level, which do not consider the basic statistical indicators such as error bars, mean, and variance. The results in Figs. 4 and 5 are computed with general setting ruler for the system parameters \(n,m,q,\sigma\) with 192-bit security level. The results in Figs. 6 and 7 are computed and taken the average with 1000 pieces of transactions in two different public blockchain platforms of Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum environment. The results in Figs. 8 and 9, and 10 are computed and taken the average with 1000 pieces of transactions in two different public blockchain platforms of Hyperledger Fabric. These results are enough to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed MCF model and RS scheme.

Facing with the new “data island” and privacy leakage problems in current BCCLS, this paper introduces a transaction ring signature model with multi-chain fusion mechanism. The transaction ring signature model helps establish a secure cross-chain data sharing mechanism for cold-chain logistics data-sharing between different logistics entities through BCCLS. Meanwhile, a ring signature scheme with lattice assumption has been designed for the transaction ring signature model. This scheme improves the cross-chain data sharing security, and guarantee the quantum attack security for cross-chain transaction in BCCLS. In addition, this research gives a new sight for cross-chain transaction privacy-preserving, and promotes the construction and application of practical cold-chain logistics data security protection mechanism.

The future works will focus on other related privacy enhancement measures in the logistics data sharing processes, such as cross-chain identity authentication, secret sharing, key agreement, and so on. Meanwhile, the consensus mechanism and data compression mechanism are also interesting to give considerations. Moreover, the actual deployment of the proposed MCF model and RS scheme will be executed in the BCCLS, and the throughput, latency, a dynamic node changes will be considered to evaluate the practice.

All data generated or analysed during this study are included in this published article.

Title: Algorand's Low-Energy Path to Scalable, Secure Blockchain
Description:
As blockchains scale, their environmental and social costs can rise sharply. 

Algorand stands out for consuming minimal energy even under heavy network load while delivering instant finality, 100% uptime, high throughput and consistently low fees.

For Algorand, a sustainable blockchain blends security and scale with the smallest possible footprint – minimising energy use while upholding user rights and transparency through resilient governance.

The Algorand Foundation steers ecosystem growth: maintaining core infrastructure and technical standards, providing a best-in-class developer environment, supporting entrepreneurs and enabling decentralised governance. The mission extends to high-impact applications such as supply-chain traceability, carbon markets and tokenised renewables.

Launched in 2019 by Turing Award–winning cryptographer Silvio Micali, Algorand has grown into a vibrant community of developers, entrepreneurs and enterprise adopters. 

Millions of users benefit from low fees and instant finality, with builders able to code in familiar languages like Python.

In this Q&A for Technology Magazine, Marc Vanlerberghe, Chief Strategy and Marketing Officer – who helped launch Android at Google – and Matt Keller, Head of Impact and Inclusion – formerly with the UN World Food Programme, One Laptop per Child and the Global Learning XPRIZE – share how Algorand is scaling sustainable, transparent and future‑ready blockchain solutions across industries.

Marc: Having verifiable, trusted sustainability programmes is key – and not just because many companies are under pressure from regulators and consumers to prove their sustainability claims. 

Algorand helps by giving them a way to record data about their sustainability – from product origins to the supply chain's footprint – on the blockchain, so their efforts are immutable, transparent and verifiable.

Supply chains can be fragmented and prone to fraud, making it hard to verify sustainability claims without a trusted digital infrastructure. 

Algorand addresses that gap, ensuring data integrity – tamper-proof, time-stamped records – and giving consumers and regulators confidence that claims are accurate. 

Algorand's high throughput and reliability allow it to handle complex, high-volume supply chains on a global scale.

Because Algorand itself is carbon neutral, businesses can rely on a platform that aligns with their sustainability commitments and ESG goals.

Matt: Some of the companies building on Algorand include Wholechain, which uses Algorand to provide end-to-end traceability for supply chains in industries like seafood and personal care. 

Every step of a product's journey is immutably recorded, helping prove ethical sourcing, authenticity and sustainability. 

Another one is Finboot, which works with major enterprises, including those in the oil and gas industry, to integrate blockchain into their supply chain management. 

This helps track raw materials and processes, providing a verifiable record of sustainability practices across industrial sectors.

Marc: Transparent carbon monitoring – and transparent carbon markets – are one piece of the puzzle to reducing carbon emissions, but many existing systems are siloed. 

Algorand helps companies record verified emissions data in real time on the blockchain. 

And by combining blockchain with Internet of Things (IoT) devices and AI, projects can automate monitoring, reduce costs and make verification more reliable.

This creates opportunities for both enterprises and households – usually excluded from these markets – to participate in carbon markets, turning emission reductions into credits that can be applied toward income or energy payments. 

Algorand's speed, low fees and efficiency make it possible to scale these kinds of carbon markets. 

The Algorand Foundation also shows this in practice by offsetting its own footprint every year through ClimateTrade, a marketplace built on Algorand. 

An impressive example of this is Ureca, which uses Algorand with IoT and machine learning to verify carbon reduction projects. 

Emissions data is collected and logged on Algorand in real time, creating trusted records for investors, regulators and communities. 

The platform enables households and enterprises to measure emissions, generate credits and apply them to bills or income. 

Marc: Absolutely. 

The tokenisation of renewables is what makes them more accessible to everyone, no matter where they live.

Many people cannot, for example, install rooftop solar because they live in apartments or in restricted buildings. 

Tokenisation on Algorand makes renewable energy accessible to them – meaning they can benefit from renewable energy projects – without having the direct infrastructure. 

Tokenisation allows you to create a fungible or non-fungible token version of an asset. These tokens then represent fractional ownership of an asset like solar or wind farms. 

This model creates inclusion in the green transition and makes clean energy more widely available. 

Enel, one of the largest energy utilities in the world, partnered with Conio to launch the EBITTS project on the Algorand blockchain. 

The project tokenises Enel's renewable assets, allowing consumers to purchase Energy Utility Tokens representing fractional ownership in solar and wind plants. 

Token holders can receive bill discounts tied to the energy their share produces and track usage through a mobile app. 

This model provides millions of people in apartments or shared housing with a direct opportunity to benefit from renewable energy. 

Enel launched in Italy, but we expect it will be replicated globally.

Marc: Algorand was designed as an environmentally friendly blockchain from the start, with sustainability built into the technology itself. 

Our consensus mechanism, Pure Proof-of-Stake (PPoS), uses far less energy than other PoS systems – and running a node on our blockchain also requires minimal hardware, meaning our blockchain is easier to scale without massive data centres.

Matt: We're proud that the Crypto Carbon Ratings Institute (CCRI) acknowledged us for this, with our annualised CO₂ use being seven times lower than Ethereum. 

And we offset our existing minimal footprint every year through projects purchased on ClimateTrade, with all offsets recorded transparently on-chain.

Matt: Blockchain has been questioned for its environmental impact, especially the early Proof of Work systems that required immense amounts of energy to run computations. 

This is one reason why the industry is moving toward greener models – and also why we see companies migrating to Algorand.

Marc: Other chains are also progressing on this front, but one obstacle remains: how well these other blockchains can scale. 

As they get more traffic and add more computers to their network, that means more compute power – and electricity – is required. 

One way blockchain can continue to be more conscious is to make its hardware requirements lighter, like that of Algorand, and to take actions like purchasing offsets, so any existing carbon footprint is managed. 

Chief Strategy & Marketing Officer

Director of Impact and Inclusion

Technology Magazine connects the leading technology executives of the world's largest brands. Our platform serves as a digital hub for connecting industry leaders, covering a wide range of services including media and advertising, events, research reports, demand generation, information, and data services. With our comprehensive approach, we strive to provide timely and valuable insights into best practices, fostering innovation and collaboration within the technology community. Join us today and shape the future for generations to come.

Title: The Tug-of-War: Centralized Control in Blockchain Governance
Description:
The world of blockchain governance is a battleground between centralized control and decentralized decision-making. On one hand, there's the allure of decentralization, promising community empowerment and inclusivity. But on the other, centralized leadership offers compliance, efficiency, and a clear direction. So, how do projects strike this delicate balance? That's the question we'll explore in this article. 

The shift from centralized authority to decentralized governance is a double-edged sword. Sure, centralization can lead to a power grab by a select few, which is ironic given that blockchain was born out of a desire for open, distributed control. This re-centralization can make governance feel more like a traditional monopoly than a decentralized utopia. 

But then again, decentralized governance can also lead to its own set of issues. Think about plutocracy, where the richest token holders have the loudest voices. Token-weighted voting can quickly turn into a breeding ground for collusion, prioritizing short-term profits over the long-term health of the ecosystem. 

In the nascent stages of blockchain projects, strong executive leadership is not just helpful; it's essential. Leaders like Antony Turner, founder of BlockDAG, aren't just figureheads; they are the navigators steering the ship through uncharted waters. They secure partnerships and help ensure compliance with regulations. Their experience in operational execution and strategic foresight is invaluable for maneuvering through the complexities of blockchain technology.

But as these projects mature, the need for decentralized governance becomes more pronounced. Community engagement and transparency are essential for fostering trust. A well-structured governance model can allow for community participation in decision-making, ensuring a variety of perspectives are considered.

In traditional corporate governance, you have a clear hierarchy: boards, executives, and shareholders. Decision-making is centralized, but there's a semblance of accountability through legal frameworks and audits. This structure is stable but can be sluggish to adapt and rife with conflicts of interest. 

Blockchain governance, however, offers a more dynamic alternative. With decentralized decision-making, there is potential for increased transparency and adaptability. But transitioning to this model is no walk in the park. It requires meticulous planning to avoid governance capture by a handful of stakeholders.

To balance effective decision-making with community engagement in decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs), several strategies can be employed. Open communication and transparent decision-making processes instill trust. Voting mechanisms like token-based voting or delegation empower the community. Decentralized dispute resolution platforms maintain moral high ground, and incentives for participation keep the community engaged. Finally, a solid technical infrastructure can enhance efficiency and security.

Effective treasury management is critical for the longevity of crypto projects. Startups need to embrace best practices like asset diversification, robust security measures, and regular financial audits. 

The governance landscape in blockchain is an ever-evolving one, increasingly caught between centralized leadership and decentralized decision-making. By understanding the pitfalls of decentralization and employing effective community engagement strategies, blockchain projects can find their footing. As the industry matures, the relationship between leadership and community governance will shape the future of decentralized technology, leading to a more inclusive and transparent ecosystem.

Key Takeaways

Spot ETFs for altcoins like SOL, LTC, and HBAR debuted in October 2025, signaling a crucial shift and a maturing crypto market beyond Bitcoin and Ethereum.

Bitwise's Solana Staking ETF (BSOL) led the altcoin ETF debut with $217.2M in AUM, offering a unique staking feature for potential yield.

The ETFs launched during a US government shutdown, bypassing standard SEC review and setting a significant regulatory precedent.

LTC and HBAR ETFs saw subdued initial flows and higher 0.95% management fees, but the launches are expected to accelerate filings for other Layer-1 platforms.

The landscape of exchange-traded funds (ETF) in the cryptocurrency sector experienced a crucial shift in October 2025, moving beyond the established dominance of Bitcoin and Ethereum. 

This period brought the debut of spot ETFs tracking several significant altcoins, most notably Solana (SOL), Litecoin (LTC), and Hedera (HBAR). 

These new spot ETFs mark a critical expansion of regulated investment vehicles available to Wall Street participants. On Tuesday, October 28, 2025, an event underscored growing institutional acceptance of these digital assets as viable investments for those initiatives.

Crucially, the launches, including the Bitwise Solana Staking ETF (BSOL), Canary HBAR ETF (HBR), and Canary Litecoin ETF (LTCC), occurred during an ongoing U.S. government shutdown. Issuers utilized S-1 provisions and 8-A filings to achieve registration effectiveness automatically after the mandatory waiting period, bypassing the standard SEC review that the shutdown would otherwise halt.

Source: Blockworks

Learn more: Fed Policy: Two Rate Cuts Locked In, 2026 Remains Ambiguous

Solana, consistently ranking among the top cryptos by market capitalization, dominated the initial narrative.

The Bitwise Solana Staking ETF (BSOL) supporting staking functionality, led the charge, starting with a strong initial asset size of approximately $220 million.

Initial trading figures on October 28, 2025, confirmed SOL's dominance:

Confirmed. The Exchange has just posted listing notices for Bitwise Solana, Canary Litecoin and Canary HBAR to launch TOMORROW and grayscale Solana to convert the day after. Assuming there's not some last min SEC intervention, looks like this is happening. https://t.co/bHwRnc1jsn

— Eric Balchunas (@EricBalchunas) October 27, 2025



Following closely on Bitwise's heels, asset management giant Grayscale also secured approval for the listing of its Grayscale Solana Trust ETF (GSOL). Grayscale received clearance to list GSOL on the NYSE Arca exchange, with trading expected to begin on Wednesday, October 29, 2025, the day following the initial launches.

By converting its existing closed-end trust, Grayscale immediately introduced a powerful competitor into the Solana ETF race. Analysts believe this high-profile listing will dramatically boost SOL's liquidity and solidify its status as a premier institutional-grade digital asset.

Canary Capital was the first to market with ETFs for Litecoin (LTC) and Hedera (HBAR), also launching on October 28, 2025. Canary CEO Steven McClurg highlighted the value proposition: LTC for its long-standing record of security and reliability, and HBAR for its position at the center of enterprise-scale digital asset utilization.

However, the initial reception for these two assets was more subdued:

Furthermore, the management fee structure for the Canary products stood at 0.95%. This figure notably exceeds the lower averages seen in established spot Bitcoin ETFs, which often range between 0.15% and 0.25%. Market observers suggest that if investor interest remains robust, competitors are likely to introduce lower-fee alternatives to capture market share.

The debut of these spot ETFs fundamentally broadens the investment narrative beyond simple price tracking. For instance, the Solana product incorporates staking mirrors, a trend where issuers actively seek features that align with the underlying blockchain's functionality. Thus, this adds utility and potential yield to the traditional ETF wrapper.

Learn more: Crypto Regulation Wave in Southeast Asia – Vietnam Joins the Race

Building upon this foundation, the combined success of the SOL staking ETF and the prompt entry of major players like Grayscale will catalyze other asset managers to accelerate filings for additional established Layer-1 platforms. Therefore, this influx of regulated capital will profoundly impact liquidity, market accessibility, and long-term price discovery for SOL, LTC, and HBAR, ultimately structurally realigning how major digital assets integrate into mainstream investment portfolios.

Furthermore, the high trading volumes seen in the first wave will likely accelerate institutional scrutiny and capital flows toward promising mid-cap altcoins, particularly those with strong technical foundations.

Learn more: Citi Bank: Stablecoins Could Reach $3.7 Trillion by 2030

Title: ICO fines sole trader for allegedly sending 1M spam texts
Description:
Britain's data watchdog has fined a sole trader £200,000 for nearly a million spam texts targeting people in debt – almost 20 pence per message.

Bharat Singh Chand sent 966,449 messages about debt solutions and energy saving grants from 383 mobile numbers between December 3, 2023, and July 3, 2024, according to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). This resulted in the fine confirmed today.

The activities of the Carmarthenshire sole trader, who has appealed against the decision, came to the attention of the regulator during a separate investigation into someone suspected of sending texts on behalf of Chand and giving advice about a SIM farm.

The messages, the ICO claims, didn't include a website address or any identifying information about the sender, simply inviting the recipient to reply "YES" to find out more about debt services. Those that replied in the affirmative received a phone call from a company calling themselves "The Debt Relief Team."

When officials from the ICO visited Chand's home with a search warrant on June 11 last year, he denied involvement in the scheme "despite a call script being on open display," the watchdog said.

Other "evidence" included WhatsApp messages between Chand and a third party that involved "discussing excuses to provide to another related ICO investigation" in which he appeared to encourage another person to "lie" in response to a letter sent by the Commissioner.

A whopping 19,138 complaints were received about the spam texts via the 7726 spam reporting service. The ICO penalized Chand, saying he "knowingly and deliberately transmitted or instigated the transmission of 966,449 text messages without valid consent, breaking direct marketing rules."

Chand has been a registered director of seven companies: Compensation Claims Direct, Consumer Claims Ltd, Consumer Marketing Solutions Limited, Platinum Home Designs Ltd, Databook Ltd, Bombay Bites Takeaway Ltd, and Blue Box Pictures Ltd.

Andy Curry, ICO head of investigations, said in a statement: "These text messages not only caused a nuisance to many thousands of recipients, but were clearly targeted at people who are at greater risk of harm; such as those facing financial hardship.

"Chand showed blatant disregard of the law and attempted to mislead the ICO during our investigation. We've taken action to protect the public from the stress and misery these messages can cause."

Because Chand appealed, the 20 percent discount on the £200,000 fine – which would have applied if it had been paid by October 16 – is not available, the ICO said. ®
